bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, May 22, 1936

div1.p: Kean thanks Truby for his kind words, and for supporting the "true" story of the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, May 22, 1936

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
May 22
1936

div1.p:
Your good letter was
full of interesting and valua-
ble information; and the kind
things that you said about me
were most gratifying to me
I dont know why I have been
so long in writing to tell you
of the pleasure it gave me,
except, though I dont have
much to do, it takes me a long
time to do it- I have not
heard from Dr. Ramos since
he returned fromto Cuba - When
I do if he still is keen to put
AC
T
put the tablet to Lazear at
Las Animas, I will follow your
suggestion and advise him to do
so, as the temporary building in
which Lazear kept his mos-
quitoes & had his little labora-
tory at Columbia Bks Hospital
has long ago disappeared-
In view of the published state-
ments about his infection and
the fact that Lazear took the
details with him to the grave
it is best not to start any
discussion-

Your intimate knowledge of the
details of this thrilling and epo-
chal episode has been of great
value to me in completing my
knowledge of them and confirm-
ing and correcting my memory
3
of them where the records were
deficient- I would like to
take your letter to Gen Reynolds
and suggest that he put it on
file with the voluminous corres-
pondence that grew up over the
“Yellow Fever Roll of Honor”, & the
various claims for recognition &
for pensions in connection with
it- I would like first to have
your permission to do so how-
ever - Also I am a little shame
faced because of the five things
that you have to say in connec-
tion with my efforts during more
than 30 years to keep the record
straight and honest- It makes
me proud to have you say that
I have succeeded so well-
AC
T
4
Of course without the constant
and unswerving talking of
Gen. Ireland it could not
have been done, nor could I
have the heart to keep at it
if you, who knew, had not been
always available to bear witness
to the facts in your clear and
fearless way- General Ireland
knows that my memory is not
as good as his (or yours) and
perhaps might have hesitated
to oppose demands backed by
Representative and Senators
including at times the heads
of the two military Committees
if you had not always sus-
tained me- Now I think that
things are pretty safe, even in-
-cluding
5

GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
the demands of that very clever
and good looking widow Mrs
Roger P. Ames & her backer Sena-
tor Sheppard, but it is just as
well to have your statement on
file as what the French call a
piece justicative-

Gen. Ireland is away as he has
been most of the spring but expects
to be back for a few weeks about
the middle of June- He will be
here for a day on May 28 when
Gen Pershing is giving a great
dinner to those who sailed with
him on the Baltic May 28 1917-
He is coming last for that sole
purpose as he naturally would
AC
T
6
not miss it- If you come east
be sure to let me know at once
I go out so little that my best
friends may be in town and
I may not hear of it unless
they let me know-

Mrs Kean joins me in cordial
regards to you both and
I am always
